P.title: Will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources

Q.title: Will the Eurozone collapse before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as "yes" if, at any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency.
Fine Print
Edit: on April 17, 2022, clarified that "no longer the de facto primary currency" means for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, not just any one of those three.

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur by 2030: (a) Any state tests a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT and (b) The Eurozone collapses?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following occur:
(a) By January 1, 2030, there are reports by reputable sources of any state testing a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT.
(b) At any time between December 1, 2020, to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency.
Fine Print
Edit: on April 17, 2022, clarified that "no longer the de facto primary currency" means for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, not just any one of those three.

P.title: Will any state test a nuclear weapon with yield above 30 MT by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2030, there are reports of such a test by reputable sources

metadata.background_info:
This is one of several questions in this tournament focused on nuclear proliferation, force sizes, or yields. See here for a list of such questions and some discussion of these topics.
Whether any country has very high-yield nuclear weapons in its arsenal is relevant both for understanding the total risk posed by nuclear weapons and for understanding how to reduce that risk.

Q.title: Will the Eurozone collapse before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as "yes" if, at any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency.
Fine Print
Edit: on April 17, 2022, clarified that "no longer the de facto primary currency" means for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, not just any one of those three.

metadata.background_info:
In response to the COVID-19 crisis, various EU-skeptics are talking about a possible collapse of the Eurozone. For instance, April 7, 2020, Gatestone Institute: Coronavirus: The Looming Collapse of Europe's Single Currency quotes:
Achim Truger, a member of the German Council of Economic Experts, said that he believes that coronabonds are necessary to prevent a collapse of the euro:
"All countries in Europe are being hit by the epidemic — Italy and Spain particularly hard. All countries, including Germany, must therefore be able to make the necessary health expenditures and take measures to bridge the economic crisis. This is only possible through additional government debt, and this must be guaranteed to prevent another euro crisis. If the debt loads of Italy and Spain rise sharply, they will be pushed into budget cuts, thus economic, social and political crises, which would ultimately lead to a sovereign debt crisis and a collapse of the euro and the EU. Therefore, there must now be a joint, solidarity-based solution."

reasons: Geopolitical instability: A state testing a nuclear weapon with a yield above 30 MT could indicate significant geopolitical tensions, which might also affect the stability of the Eurozone.
Economic sanctions: A nuclear test of this magnitude could lead to severe economic sanctions, which might have ripple effects on the global economy, including the Eurozone.
Global security concerns: Heightened global security concerns could lead to shifts in economic policies and alliances, potentially impacting the Eurozone.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as significant geopolitical events can have wide-ranging economic and political impacts.

verification_result.reasoning: The event described in R is the conjunction of the events described in P and Q. R will resolve positively if and only if both P and Q resolve positively. Therefore, R is the logical conjunction of P and Q.

P.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

Q.title: In the 2024 US presidential election, will any state refuse to certify their election results?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline. The "safe harbor" deadline for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th

P_and_Q.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) More than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050 (b) Any state refuses to certify their election results in the 2024 US presidential election?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
(a) This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device. For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use). Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion.
(b) The question will resolve positively if any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline. The "safe harbor" deadline for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th.

P.title: Will more than 50% of US adults own a personal augmented reality device by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if anytime before January 1, 2050, a credible survey of adults in the US suggests that more than 50% of US adults own any type of personal augmented reality device.
For the purposes of this question, a personal augmented reality device is defined as one which is portable and intended to accompany a person from place to place, and whose primary use is in augmented reality functions. "Augmented reality functions" are defined as producing digital information and images overlaid over the user's view of their real environment, which update in real time as the user moves and interacts with the digital and physical environment. A handheld smartphone which is occasionally used as an augmented reality device would not qualify (as AR is not its primary use).
Where there is reason to believe a survey captures a significant number of devices that do not qualify for question resolution the admins shall use their best judgement or use an alternate survey or method if available, or resolve the question as ambiguous at their discretion

metadata.background_info:
The Merriam-Webster Dictionary defines augmented reality (AR) as
an enhanced version of reality created by the use of technology to overlay digital information on an image of something being viewed through a device (such as a smartphone camera)
Some expect AR devices to be much more prevalent in the future. Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about augmented reality in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
By 2050 pretty much everyone will be wearing smart glasses for augmented reality, and eventually these glasses will replace a lot of phones (no one will carry a wallet in 2050).
According to a PEW survey, 85% of US adults said they owned a smartphone in 2021.

Q.title: In the 2024 US presidential election, will any state refuse to certify their election results?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question will resolve positively if any state (or DC) does not certify their results by the "safe harbor" deadline. The "safe harbor" deadline for the 2024 presidential election will be December 10th

metadata.background_info:
Recent controversy over state election laws has caused some Democrats to be concerned that Republicans intend to use their political power in state governments to distort future elections in their favor. One commentator recently suggested:
"If a Democrat wins a GOP-controlled swing state in 2024 … there’s a very good chance the victory isn’t certified"
Election certification is the process in which states confirm the election results and declare them to be the official results. Typically states set their own deadlines for election certification, which in 2020 ranged from November 5th to December 8th for the presidential contest (several states appear to have no deadline), but federal law provides a "safe harbor" deadline by which states must formally certify their election results in order for the certified results to be federally recognized as governing the outcome. The "safe harbor" deadline is set by 3 U.S. Code § 5 and 3 U.S. Code § 7 which sets the safe harbor deadline as six days prior to the first Monday after the second Wednesday in December of the election year.

reasons: The adoption of augmented reality (AR) devices could influence the way people consume news and information, potentially affecting political opinions and actions. This could lead to increased polarization or misinformation, which might contribute to a state refusing to certify election results.
Widespread use of AR devices could also lead to new forms of election monitoring and reporting, which might uncover irregularities or fraud that could cause a state to refuse to certify results.
The political climate and technological landscape are both evolving, and the intersection of these two trends could have unforeseen consequences on election processes.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, particularly in the context of how technology might influence political processes.

verification_result.reasoning: R is a conjunction of P and Q because it requires both conditions (a) and (b) to be true for it to resolve positively. Condition (a) corresponds to P, and condition (b) corresponds to Q. Therefore, R is true if and only if both P and Q are true.

P.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. (If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously.)
If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered

Q.title: Will a senolytic therapy for a companion animal be commercially available before one for humans?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Similar to the linked question’s criterion, “an intervention will be regarded as a 'senolytic therapy' if it is marketed by its producer as an intervention whose purpose includes the selective removal of senescent cells”. This function must be verified by a reputable third party, such as the FDA or major medical journals. An impact on lifespan need not be demonstrated for either the animal or the human therapy.
Fine Print
If a therapy for animals is sold before a human therapy is approved and sold, but the animal therapy is only verified by a third party afterwards, the question will still resolve positively.

P_and_Q.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030 and will a senolytic therapy for a companion animal be commercially available before one for humans?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
1. This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. (If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously.)
If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered.

2. This question also resolves positively if a senolytic therapy for a companion animal is sold before a human therapy is approved and sold, and the animal therapy is verified by a reputable third party, such as the FDA or major medical journals. An impact on lifespan need not be demonstrated for either the animal or the human therapy. If a therapy for animals is sold before a human therapy is approved and sold, but the animal therapy is only verified by a third party afterwards, the question will still resolve positively.

P.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. (If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously.)
If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered

metadata.background_info:
On April 22, 2021, President Joe Biden pledged to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 50 to 52% in 2030, compared to 2005 levels.
A statement from the White House writes:
Today, President Biden will announce a new target for the United States to achieve a 50-52 percent reduction from 2005 levels in economy-wide net greenhouse gas pollution in 2030 – building on progress to-date and by positioning American workers and industry to tackle the climate crisis.
According to the Center for Climate and Energy Solutions, net emissions in 2017 were 5,743 million metric tons of CO₂ equivalents, 12% lower than in 2005. Net emissions in 2020 were 21% below 2005 levels and 10.3% lower than 2019 levels, according to a preliminary report by Rhodium Group, but emission levels are expected to rise in 2021 as pandemic lockdown measures are reduced.

Q.title: Will a senolytic therapy for a companion animal be commercially available before one for humans?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Similar to the linked question’s criterion, “an intervention will be regarded as a 'senolytic therapy' if it is marketed by its producer as an intervention whose purpose includes the selective removal of senescent cells”. This function must be verified by a reputable third party, such as the FDA or major medical journals. An impact on lifespan need not be demonstrated for either the animal or the human therapy.
Fine Print
If a therapy for animals is sold before a human therapy is approved and sold, but the animal therapy is only verified by a third party afterwards, the question will still resolve positively.

metadata.background_info: A Metaculus question asks about the approval for commercial sale of human senolytics, drugs that induce removal of senescent cells to delay or reverse aging. Other types of anti-aging therapies are being developed for dogs, with the benefit of serving as stepping stones to similar therapies for humans, helping to fill scientific, financial, and regulatory gaps.

reasons: The development and commercialization of senolytic therapies could be influenced by regulatory environments, which might also impact policies on greenhouse gas emissions.
Both questions involve significant scientific and technological advancements, which could be driven by broader societal trends towards innovation and sustainability.
Public and governmental interest in health and environmental issues might be correlated, potentially influencing funding and policy decisions in both areas.
relevance.conclusion: There are some indirect connections between the two questions, primarily through regulatory, societal, and technological factors. However, these connections are not strong or direct.

verification_result.reasoning: The event described in R is the conjunction of the events described in P and Q. R will be true if and only if both P and Q are true. Specifically, R requires both that US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030 and that a senolytic therapy for a companion animal be commercially available before one for humans. This matches the logical conjunction of the two separate events described in P and Q.
